Summary: The proposal aims to bridge the gap between correlation and causation in AI by developing dynamic graph-based models that can infer and adapt causal structures over time. It addresses limitations in current methods, such as static representations and poor generalization to unseen interventions, with a hybrid architecture combining GNNs and attention-based mechanisms. The proposed method includes context-aware causal graph learning, intervention-aware representation learning, and efficient counterfactual simulation. The experiment plan is comprehensive, covering synthetic benchmarks, real-world datasets, high-dimensional data, and computational efficiency.
Strengths: Ambitious and original hypothesis focusing on dynamic causal relationships.
Detailed and innovative proposed method with a three-part framework.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering multiple validation scenarios.
Strong scientific rigor with planned ablation studies and comparisons to baselines.
Weaknesses: Lacks explicit discussion of potential technical challenges and risks.
Implementation details of the dynamic edge mechanism could be more clearly delineated.
Limited discussion on how the model will handle noisy or incomplete data.
No mention of potential scalability issues with very large graphs.
Questions: How will the dynamic edge mechanism be implemented and validated in practice?
What are the specific technical challenges anticipated in scaling to high-dimensional data?
How will the model handle noisy or incomplete data in real-world scenarios?
What are the potential failure modes of the proposed hybrid architecture?
Limitations: Potential scalability issues with very large graphs (>10k nodes).
Dependence on the quality and completeness of the observational data.
Risk of overfitting in the dynamic edge mechanism without sufficient regularization.
